_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
minal from 1951 until it was acquired by KMLT in March 2001.  The terminal is bounded by the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal to the west, Corn Products Corporation to the north, Archer Avenue to the east, and the Shell Oil Terminal and the Univar Distribution Facility to the south.  Bedford Park Fire Station Number 1 is located at the entrance to the Argo Terminal.  The terminal provides tank storage for liquid chemicals, petroleum, food grade products, and raw materials on a ?contract? basis.  Presently 217 permitted aboveground storage tanks are available (approximately 100,000,000 gallon capacity) for storage and distribution of customer products or for support activities.  Materials are received at the terminal by tank trucks, rail cars, barge, and pipeline.   

Of the 217 permitted aboveground storage tanks, one tank, Tank 5-15 (for storage of vinyl acetate), is covered by the RMP regulation.  Tank C-11 (storage of cyclohexylamine) was previously part of the RMP; however, this tank has since been removed from service and this RMP is an update to reflect current operations.

Policies to Protect Health, Safety and the Environment
Risk management and safety are important concerns at the Argo Terminal.  This RMP formalizes and documents these activities.  The facility is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner and to reducing risks to human health and the environment.

Prevention Program 
An Accidental Release Prevention Program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the EPA Risk Management Program requirements (40 CFR 68). This prevention program covers those processes that handle regulated substances above the threshold amount.  The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:

? Keeping process safety information accessible at all times.
? Conducting a hazard review as part of the preparation

s for RMP compliance.
? Using written operating procedures to train and guide operators.
? Providing training to all employees that operate the system.
? Operating a program to properly maintain the system and equipment.
? Investigating incidents and taking actions as part of a continuous improvement effort.
? Conducting routine audits to ensure that safe practices are followed.

Processes at the facility subject to the Risk Management Program are designed with extensive safeguards to protect against the accidental release of a hazardous material. Examples of safety equipment in place include pressure relief devices, leak detection, and alarm systems.  

In addition, process operators receive extensive training in the safe operation of the process and are required to follow detailed operating procedures to help ensure safety.  The facility also has implemented a maintenance program to monitor the physical condition of process equipment, and replace or repair equipment before it fails.

In the unlikely event of a spill or release involving a hazardous material, the Argo Terminal has developed an emergency response plan providing procedures to be followed to minimize the potential impacts of a fire at the facility. In the event of a release, the facility calls the Bedford Park Fire Department located at the facility boundary.

Hazard Evaluation
Under the EPA regulations, the facility is required to evaluate the potential consequences of a worst case release and various alternate release scenarios.  The following paragraphs provide a description of the worst case and alternate scenarios for the base. 

The RMP regulations define a worst-case release as "?the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint defined in Sections 68.22 (a)" (40 CFR 68.3). The worst-case release scenario for toxic liquids assumes that the total quantity in a vessel is spilled instantaneously o

nto a flat non-absorbing surface to form a pool.  Passive mitigation systems, such as dikes, are taken into account in the consequence analysis.  The release rate to air is estimated as the rate of evaporation from the pool of spilled toxic liquid.  Each tank at the Argo Terminal is located within a diked area 

For Tank 5-15 (capacity 187,700 gallons), it is assumed that the contents of the tank empty instantaneously to a diked area.  The diked area is capable of holding the capacity of the largest tank, plus sufficient free board to allow for precipitation.  The evaporation rate is then determined using the CHARM model to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint.

Five-Year Accident History
On September 29, 1996 the Argo Terminal experienced a release of vinyl acetate, a listed RMP chemical.  During a severe thunderstorm, heavy winds knocked a piece of equipment from the roof of a nearby tank, resulting in a ruptured pipe on Tank 5-16, which, at the time was used to store vinyl acetate.  An estimated 9,000 gallons of vinyl acetate was released to the diked area.  Because of the severe weather, the dike drains had been left open to prevent flooding of the diked area.  As a result, the material was discharged to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District sanitary sewer system. No material was discharged to a waterway or over land. The discharge did not result in any on-site or off-site deaths or injuries, evacuations, or sheltering in place. Whether the MWRD was able to treat the release or whether it passed through the treatment system and was discharged to waterways is unknown; therefore the environmental impacts of this release are undetermined.

For the 2004 RMP update, KMLT reported that no accidents had occurred during the previous five years. No accidents have occurred since the 2004 update was submitted.


Emergency Response Plan
The RMP regulations require that "response actions have been coordinated with local emergency planning and response agencies"

(40 CFR 68.12(b)(3)).   Emergency response activities at  the Argo Terminal are coordinated with the Cook County Central LEPC and Bedford Park Fire Department.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Safety and Emergency Preparedness is a part of the facility?s activities.  Exposure risks to employees and the public have been minimized through ongoing inspections, maintenance, and capital improvements.  Further improvements will continue to be implemented as appropriate.
